===Etymology 1===
From {{inh-lite|en|enm|Mars}}, from {{der-lite|en|la|Mars|Mārs|god of war}}, from older Latin (older than 75 {{BC}}) {{m-lite|la|Mavors|Māvors}}.

====Proper noun====
{{en-proper noun|+|plqual=rare}}

# {{senseid|en|Q111}} {{lb|en|astronomy}} The fourth planet in the [[solar system]]. Symbol: '''[[♂]]'''
#: {{ux|en|'''Mars''' has two moons, Deimos and Phobos.}}
#* {{quote-book|en|author={{w|John Wyndham}} [pseudonym; John Wyndham Parkes Lucas Beynon Harris]|chapter=Phase One|title=w:The Kraken Wakes|location=Harmondsworth, Middlesex|publisher=[[w:Penguin Books|Penguin Books Ltd]]|year=1953|year_published=1966|page=12|passage=‘There’s another one. There can’t be two '''Marses''',’ said Phyllis. / And sure enough there was. A smaller red point, a little up from, and to the right of, the first.}}
#* {{quote-book|en|author=[[w:Philip K. Dick|Philip K[indred] Dick]]|chapter=[To Carol Carr]|title=The Selected Letters of Philip K. Dick|volume=!1 (1938–1971)|location=Grass Valley, Calif.|publisher=Underwood Books|date=30 November 1964|year_published=1996|page=136|pageurl=https://archive.org/details/philip-k.-dick-the-selected-letters-of-philip-k.-dick-1938-1971-volume-1-underwood-books-1997/page/136/mode/1up|isbn=1-887424-20-2|passage=Well, see, we’re building a steam-driven solar system from a kit. (Cheaper than the Japanese miniaturized, transistorized models, which have two '''Marses''' and no Earth sometimes.)}}
#* {{quote-book|en|author=[[w:Ian Watson (author)|Ian Watson]]|chapter=Mummy-cloth|title=The Martian Inca|location=London|publisher=w:Victor Gollancz Ltd|year=1977|section=section four|page=47|pageurl=https://archive.org/details/martianinca0000wats/page/47/mode/1up|passage=The planet '''Mars''', seen by Cro-Magnon eyes, presumably was a blue summer world with air and water. Winter '''Mars''', seen by modem man, a red ice-capped desert. Two '''Marses''' coincided briefly in his mind’s eye, then rushed apart into endless cycles of Red and Blue … Human fingers intended to halt '''Mars''' at the moment of perfection, and hold a whole world there!}}
#* {{quote-web
|en
|date=22 September 2018
|author=Marissa Carruthers
|title=Five of the best places to go off grid in Asia, get back to nature and away from office phone calls
|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20180923131304/https://www.scmp.com/lifestyle/travel-leisure/article/2165203/five-best-places-go-grid-asia-get-back-nature-and-away
|archivedate=23 September 2018
|work=w:South China Morning Post
|section=Travel & Leisure
|text=With its '''Mars'''-like landscape, visiting Gurbantunggut Desert feels like escaping to another world.}}
# {{senseid|en|Q112}} {{lb|en|Roman god}} The [[Roman]] [[god]] of [[war]].
#: {{syn|en|Ares}}
#: {{ux|en|'''Mars''' was the lover of Venus, and together they had a daughter called Harmonia.}}
# {{lb|en|poetic}} [[war|War]]; a [[personification]] of war.
#: {{ux|en|In the first half of the twentieth century, '''Mars''' devastated Europe.}}
#* {{quote-book|en|passage='''Mars''' rode upon the storm of horror and drank his fill of pain and blood. When the Serbian Army retreated before the foe, four times its own strength, it went backward facing the enemy and fighting every step of the way.|title=A Nation at Bay: What an American Woman Saw and Did in Suffering Serbia|page=57|author=Ruth Stanley Farnam|year=1918}}
#* {{quote-journal|en|passage=A relieved world then will eagerly turn to the task of reclaiming the destruction wrought by '''Mars''' ... A tremendous task, filled with infinite possibilities ... A profitable task, according to how well you are prepared to do your part in the rehabilitation ...|magazine=Engineering and Mining Journal|volume=145|page=54|year=1944|author=McGraw-Hill}}
#* {{quote-book|en|passage=The plague, inevitable companion of '''Mars''', ravaged the populace.|title=Jacques Callot: Prints & Related Drawings, Issue 21|author=Helen Diane Russell; Jeffrey Blanchard|year=1975|page=10}}

====Noun====
{{en-noun|-}}

# {{lb|en|tincture|rare}} {{cap|gules}} {{gloss|red}}, in the [[postmedieval]] practice of [[blazon]]ing the tinctures of certain sovereigns' (especially British monarchs') coats as planets.
#* {{quote-text|en|year=1693|author=Richard Blome|title=The Art of Heraldry, in two parts ... second edition ...|pages=76-77
|passage=4. ''Luna'', a ''Mantle'' of ''Estate'', ''Mars'' doubled Ermine, ouched ''Sol'', garnished with Strings fastned thereunto fretways dependent, and tasselled of the same. [...] These Arms do belong to the Town of ''Beckbock'' in ''Wales''. 5. ''Jupiter'', a ''Mace'' of ''Majestry'' in ''Bend Sol''. [...] 12. ''Venus'', a ''Staff'' in Pale ''Sol'', and thereupon a ''Cross Pattee'', ''Luna'' surmounted off a ''Pall'' of the last, charged with 4. like Crosses fitched Saturn, edged and stringed as the second. This ''Coat'' belongs to the ''Archiepiscopal See of Canterbury'', to whose place it appertains to Crown and Inaugurate the Kings of ''England''.}}
#* {{quote-book|en|year=1718|author=Samuel Kent|title=The Grammar of Heraldry [...] Second Edition
|text=George [...] I''st.'' Mars, three Lions passant guardant in Pale Sol, for the Arms of ''England'', Impal'd with ''Scotland'', i.e. Sol, a Lion rampant within a double Tressure counterflory Mars. 2d. Jupiter, three Fleurs de Lis Sol, for the Arms of ''France''. 3d. Jupiter, an Irish Harp Sol, stringed Luna, for ''Ireland''. 4th. Seme party per Pale, and per Chevron enarche, in the Ist Mars, two Lions passant guardant Sol, for ''Brunswick''. In the 2d Partition Sol, semy of Hearts Mars, and a Lion rampant Jupiter, armed and langued of the First, for ''Luneburg''. The base is Mars, a Horse currant Luna, over these last on an Inescocheon, Constantine's Crown. All within the Garter. Above the whole a Helmet suitable to his Majesty's Royal Jurisdiction, upon the same a rich Mantle of Cloth of Gold, doubled Ermine, a{{nb...}}}}
#* {{quote-book|en|year=1735|author=Francis Nichols|title=The Irish Compendium [...] vol. III of the British Compendium, second edition|page=80
|text=8. Tierce in Mantle, first Mars, two Lions passant-guardant in pale, Sol, for Brunswick; 2d Sol, Semi of Hearts proper, a Lion rampant Jupiter, for Lunenburgh; 3d, ente en Point, Mars, an Horse currant Luna, for Saxony. Note, these Ensigns (which are the paternal Coat of his Majesty King George) I have added as an Example, to shew the Form of what foreign Heralds term Tierce in Mantle, ente en Pointe, &c. {{...}} }}
#* {{quote-book|en|year=1737|author=Benjamin Martin|title=Bibliotheca Technologica: Or, a Philological Library|page=631
|passage=ARMS. QUARTERLY, in the first grand Quarter ''Mars'', three Lions passant-guardant in Pale, ''Sol''; the ''Imperial Ensigns'' of ''England'', impaled with the ''Royal Arms'' of ''Scotland'', which are ''Sol'', a Lion rampant within a double Tressure flower'd and counterflower'd with Fleurs-de-lis, ''Mars''. The second Quarter is the ''Royal Arms'' of ''France'', viz. ''Jupiter'', three Fleurs-de-lis, ''Sol''. The third, the ''Ensign'' of ''Ireland'', which is, ''Jupiter'', an Harp ''Sol'', stringed ''Luna''.}}
# {{lb|en|obsolete|alchemy|chemistry}} [[iron|Iron]].

===Etymology 2===
[[File:MBar 700.jpg|thumb|UK-style Mars bar]]

After {{w|Franklin Clarence Mars}}, who founded the company that produces these chocolate bars. His surname is possibly a variant of {{m|en|Marrs}},<ref>{{R:en:DAFN}}</ref> itself from {{m|en|Marr}} with post-medieval excrescent ''-s''.<ref>{{R:en:DAFN|Marrs}}</ref>

====Proper noun====
{{en-proper noun}}

# The {{w|Mars bar}}, a [[brand]] of [[chocolate]] [[bar]] with [[caramel]] and [[nougat]] [[filling]].
#* {{quote-book|en|year=1985|author=Michael Collier|title=Longest Day|page=206|passage=Easily eight foot tall, each was big, brown and glutinous - like giant '''Mars''' Bars squeezed and welded into nightmarish sculptures.}}

==Latin==

===Etymology===
From {{der-lite|la|itc-ola|Mavors|Māvors}}, from {{inh-lite|la|itc-pro|sc=Latn|*Māwortis}},<ref>Walde, Alois & Hofmann, Johann Baptist. 1954. ''Lateinisches etymologisches Wörterbuch'', 2nd vol. (M-Z), 3rd edition, pp. 43-45.</ref> or from {{inh|la|itc-pro|*Māmart-}}. If ''Māvors'' indeed comes from ''*Māmart-'', the apparent change */-m-/ to */-w-/ is a unique and isolated change.<ref>de Vaan, Michiel. 2008. ''Etymological Dictionary of Latin and the other Italic Languages'', p. 366. </ref> ''Mamers'' was his [[w:Oscan language|Oscan]] name. He was also known as ''Marmor'', ''Marmar'' and ''Maris'', the latter from the Etruscan deity [[Maris]]. See also the [[w:Lapis Satricanus|Lapis Satricanus]], where 𐌌𐌀𐌌𐌀𐌓𐌕𐌄𐌆 (''Mamartei'') is attested. Possibly also related to {{ncog|sa|मरुत्|t={{w|Maruts}}, violent storm-gods}}.<ref>{{R:sa:EWAia|vol=2|page=322}}</ref>

===Pronunciation===
* {{la-IPA|Mārs}}

===Proper noun===
{{la-proper noun|Mārs<3>|g=m}}

# {{lb|la|Roman god}} [[#English|Mars]] {{q|[[god]] of [[war]]}}
# {{lb|la|astronomy}} [[#English|Mars]] {{q|[[planet]]}}
# {{lb|la|alchemy|chemistry}} [[iron]]

====Usage notes====
The name of the god could, through {{m-lite|la|interpretatio romana}}, serve to replace the name of a war god in a foreign language. Thus [[w:Saxo Grammaticus|Saxo Grammaticus]], for example, uses the term to refer to the Norse god [[Odin]], alternating it with the borrowed form {{m-lite|la|Othinus|Ōthinus}}.

====Declension====
{{la-ndecl|Mārs<3>}}

===Noun===
{{la-noun|Mārs<3.both>|g=m}}

# [[war]], [[battle]], [[conflict]]
#: {{uxi|la|{{l-lite|la|aequatus|aequato}} '''Marte'''|made equal the battle}}

====Declension====
{{la-ndecl|Mārs<3.both>}}
